Many evaded the performance of their promises altogether; others impudently sent aged cows3 lame, lean, and dying horses; old, bare, and diseased sheep3 and every thing else in the same style. Many of those persons whom the Governor employed in collecting or keeping the cattle and other things, were defi- cient either in fidelity or in diligence, reserving some for their own private use, and exchanging the better ones, which they kept to themselves, for others of less value. It therefore is not to be wondered at that the whole of Paraguay did not contain a more indigent or calamitous co— lony, of which I, who was forced to struggle, for two years, with extreme poverty, and the insolence of these savageS‚ had full and ocular demonstration.
